summary: This is an email chain from March 2019 discussing the logistics of transferring and uploading FBI case files related to the Epstein investigation for the US Attorney's Office in the Southern District of New York. It reveals internal coordination issues regarding obtaining a complete set of approximately 29,000 pages from a FOIA office in Washington D.C., and the uploading of data from a hard drive and video discs to a shared system for review.

events.title: Hard Drive and Discs Received from FBI
events.description: The FBI provided a hard drive and a number of video discs containing Epstein case data to the US Attorney's Office for uploading to a shared system.

events.title: Contractor Confirms Data Placement
events.description: A contractor confirms that materials from the hard drive and individual discs have been placed in designated shared network folders.

events.title: Follow-up on Incomplete Case File Transfer
events.description: An email follow-up reveals that only about 16,000 pages of an estimated 29,000-page case file had been transferred from a FOIA office in Washington D.C., causing a stall in getting the complete file for review.

keyFacts: The FBI possessed a 'large amount of data' on the Epstein case that was being transferred to the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York in March 2019.
There was an internal issue with obtaining the complete case file from a FOIA office in Washington D.C., with only approximately 16,000 pages of an estimated 29,000 pages transferred.
The transferred materials included data on a hard drive and a number of video discs, some related to a 'black book sting' investigation.
The documents were being prepared for upload to a system called 'Relativity' for legal review.
